title: Why Does the Bible Say NO to Pork? (Leviticus 11 Explained!)
description:
Leviticus 11:7 bans the eating of pork but we are not given a ton of detail about what makes it clean or unclean other than the cud and hoof chewing. Some might find this weird but pigs were often thought to be unclean animals in the ancient near east and were banned from many places. 

Leviticus 11:7
 The pig, for even though it has divided hoofs and is cleft-footed, it does not chew the cud; it is unclean for you.

title: John the Baptist was not Elijah | Bible Prophecies Debunked
description:
In the Old Testament, specifically in the book of Malachi, it is prophesied that Elijah will return before the "great and dreadful day of the Lord" (Malachi 4:5-6). This return is interpreted by many to mean that Elijah would come to prepare the way for the coming of the Messiah.

In the New Testament, the connection between John the Baptist and Elijah is explained by Jesus himself. When John begins his ministry, some people speculate that he might be Elijah, given his role in preparing the people for the Messiah's arrival (Matthew 11:14). Jesus confirms this connection in Matthew 17:10-13, where he says that John the Baptist is the Elijah who was to come. He explains that John fulfills the prophecy not by literally being Elijah reincarnated, but by coming in the spirit and power of Elijah, fulfilling the prophetic role of preparing the way for Jesus.

John's role is further emphasized in the Gospels, where he calls people to repentance and baptizes them, symbolizing a spiritual preparation for the coming of the Messiah. In a sense, John is the "Elijah-like" figure who heralds the arrival of Christ.

title: Responding to inspiring Philosophy on Numbers 31 and child brides..... Again
description:
Numbers 31:12-31

12 Then they brought the captives, the booty, and the spoil to Moses, to Eleazar the priest, and to the congregation of the children of Israel, to the camp in the plains of Moab by the Jordan, across from Jericho. 13 And Moses, Eleazar the priest, and all the leaders of the congregation, went to meet them outside the camp. 14 But Moses was angry with the officers of the army, with the captains over thousands and captains over hundreds, who had come from the battle.

15 And Moses said to them: “Have you kept all the women alive? 16 Look, these women caused the children of Israel, through the counsel of Balaam, to trespass against the Lord in the incident of Peor, and there was a plague among the congregation of the Lord. 17 Now therefore, kill every male among the little ones, and kill every woman who has known a man intimately. 18 But keep alive for yourselves all the young girls who have not known a man intimately. 19 And as for you, remain outside the camp seven days; whoever has killed any person, and whoever has touched any slain, purify yourselves and your captives on the third day and on the seventh day. 20 Purify every garment, everything made of leather, everything woven of goats’ hair, and everything made of wood.”

21 Then Eleazar the priest said to the men of war who had gone to the battle, “This is the ordinance of the law which the Lord commanded Moses: 22 Only the gold, the silver, the bronze, the iron, the tin, and the lead, 23 everything that can endure fire, you shall put through the fire, and it shall be clean; and it shall be purified with the water of purification. But all that cannot endure fire you shall put through water. 24 And you shall wash your clothes on the seventh day and be clean, and afterward you may come into the camp.”

Division of the Plunder

25 Now the Lord spoke to Moses, saying: 26 “Count up the plunder that was taken—of man and beast—you and Eleazar the priest and the chief fathers of the congregation; 27 and divide the plunder into two parts, between those who took part in the war, who went out to battle, and all the congregation. 28 And levy a tribute for the Lord on the men of war who went out to battle: one of every five hundred of the persons, the cattle, the donkeys, and the sheep; 29 take it from their half, and give it to Eleazar the priest as a heave offering to the Lord. 30 And from the children of Israel’s half you shall take one of every fifty, drawn from the persons, the cattle, the donkeys, and the sheep, from all the livestock, and give them to the Levites who keep charge of the tabernacle of the Lord.” 31 So Moses and Eleazar the priest did as the Lord commanded Moses.

title: The INSANE List of Rules for the Word of Faith Fellowship Cult
description:
The Word of Faith Fellowship church (WOFF) has been criticized and even prosecuted by former members. But it's unofficial list of rules might be the most jaw dropping artifact publicly available.

Rules can be viewed here...

https://www.familiesagainstcultthreats.org/resources/WOFF---RULES-FOR-NEW-MEMBERS.pdf

The Word of Faith Fellowship (WOFF) church, based in Spindale, North Carolina, has faced numerous legal issues and allegations over the years. Here are some key points:

1. **Allegations of Abuse**: The church has been accused of various forms of abuse, including physical, emotional, and spiritual abuse. Former members have reported being subjected to intense control, including forced confessions, physical beatings, and isolation from family and friends.

2. **Legal Cases**: Several former members have filed lawsuits against the church, claiming they were subjected to abusive practices. In some cases, the church has settled out of court, while other cases have led to criminal investigations and charges.

3. **Child Abuse Claims**: There have been multiple allegations of child abuse within the church. Some former members have testified that children were beaten in the name of discipline and subjected to harsh punishments.

4. **Human Trafficking Allegations**: In 2017, the church was investigated for allegedly smuggling Brazilian nationals into the U.S. and forcing them to work for little or no pay. These individuals were reportedly threatened with deportation if they did not comply with the church's demands.

5. **Control and Manipulation**: The church has been described as employing cult-like tactics to control its members. This includes isolation from non-church members, indoctrination, and financial exploitation.

6. **Leadership and Influence**: The church is led by Jane Whaley, who has been a central figure in many of the allegations. She has been accused of exerting a high degree of control over church members and orchestrating the abusive practices.

7. **Media Attention**: The WOFF has been the subject of numerous media investigations and reports, which have brought national and international attention to the allegations against the church. These reports have included detailed accounts from former members and investigative journalism pieces.

The church has consistently denied these allegations, stating that they are false and that the church is being unfairly targeted. However, the numerous testimonies and legal actions from former members have kept the spotlight on the church's practices and raised significant concerns about its operations.

title: Deconstruction Journey with New Testament Scholar, Dr. Jennifer Grace Bird
description:
Dr. Bird has taught in New Jersey, Texas, Tennessee, North Carolina, Oregon and Virginia. Her background within the United Methodist Church, education in a Presbyterian affiliated institution, more than a decade spent in several ministerial contexts, six years of graduate work in biblical studies, and more than 25 years of teaching in classrooms of all kinds all inform her approach to having quite honest, and sometimes difficult, conversations about what is actually to be found in the scriptures of the Christian Bible.

Her favorite conversations include
gender, sexuality, and marriage:
what the Bible does and does not say about them!

title: How To Get A Christian To Admit That Hosea 11:1-2 Is NOT A Prophecy About Jesus Coming Out Of Egypt
description:
If you take the average Christian to Hosea 11:1-2 BEFORE you let them read Matthew 2:14-15, they almost always admit that Hosea is not giving a prophecy about Jesus or that it's a prophecy at all. But then they squirm all over once they realize that Matthew says it's a prophecy. And no, typology isn't a real thing. It's subjective and silly. 

Hosea 11:1-2
When Israel was a child, I loved him,
    and out of Egypt I called my son.
2 The more I called them,
    the more they went from me;
they kept sacrificing to the Baals
    and offering incense to idols.


Matthew 2:14-15
Then Joseph got up, took the child and his mother by night, and went to Egypt 15 and remained there until the death of Herod. 
This was to fulfill what had been spoken by the Lord through the prophet, “Out of Egypt I have called my son.”

title: Not god overacting to a problem he created.....
Is Ezekiel 28 About Satan's Fall?
description:
Ezekiel 28 has a history of being used to describe the fall of Satan, however, Satan as a divine adversary had yet to exist within the cultural zeitgeist of Israel. Satan theology was developed during the Persian period and then later read back into the text. 

Ezekiel 28 is referencing Assyrian and Babylonian mythology, not the book of Genesis.

title: Did Ron Wyatt Discover The Blood of Jesus?
description:
In the 1980's, an untrained pseudo-archaeologist named Ron Wyatt claimed that he discovered the crucifixion site of Jesus, the ark of the covenant below it, and also Jesus' blood that seeped into the ground onto the ark. Not surprisingly, there were no pictures of the arc and not a single third party to verify the findings, and no peer reviewed research. Just the claims of a man that wanted to the Christian Indiana Jones. 

Not only did he not discover the blood of Jesus, he and his team hopelessly contaminated the samples collected of what appears to be garden variety sand stone and dirt. 

#ronwyatt #biblicalarchaeology #christianmythology 

key words: Ron Wyatt, blood, DNA, blood of Jesus, somatids, archaeology, biblical archaeology, contamination, blood sample, microscope, lifeblood, scams

description:

description:
This was certainly not an exhaustive account of my journey but touches on a number of key problems, such as biblical inerrancy, the treatment of women, biblical slavery, and the slaughter of the Canaanites. 

Certainly more could be said of the flood that god sent to wipe out the humans that he resented creating and the fact that natural disasters and diseases kill hundreds of thousands of people every year. 

keywords: deconstruction, biblical inerrancy, bible errors, science, DNA, slavery, Canaanites, innocence, faith, belief, church, christianity, bible study

description:

title: Seminary Educated Deconstructionist Reacts To John MacArthur's 1st Sermon On Deconstruction.
description:
It was worse than I expected. My honest take on John's entire first sermon about deconstruction which he never bothered to lookup in the dictionary. This should not be surprising since he is known to marketing his honorary Doctorate (one from his own school) as an earned Ph.D. 

For any one interested here are some definitions. 
1. A method of critical analysis of philosophical and literary language which emphasizes the internal workings of language and conceptual systems, the relational quality of meaning, and the assumptions implicit in forms of expression. (Google)

2. form of philosophical and literary analysis, derived mainly from work begun in the 1960s by the French philosopher Jacques Derrida, that questions the fundamental conceptual distinctions, or “oppositions,” in Western philosophy through a close examination of the language and logic of philosophical and literary texts. (Britannica)

#macarthur 
#deconstruction 
#predictable
